extraction.summary: This book review examines Jerome Groopman's 'How Doctors Think,' which analyzes diagnostic and treatment decision-making in medicine through case studies of both errors and successes. The reviewer highlights the book's identification of common cognitive biases in clinical practice while noting its limitation in not quantifying the prevalence of such errors.
key_claims: Physicians make diagnostic and treatment decisions through cognitive processes that can be improved
Language remains the foundation of clinical medicine despite available technologies
Algorithms must be applied within the context of the specific patient being treated
How choices are presented to patients strongly influences their decisions
Medical curricula teach little about cognitive errors and biases in clinical decision-making
Understanding why physicians get things wrong is essential to understanding how to get things right
processes: Case-based analysis of diagnostic errors and correct diagnoses to identify cognitive patterns
Comparison of cognitive processes between erroneous and successful diagnostic cases
decisions: Decision point: whether to treat or not, biased toward action (commission bias)
Decision point: when to apply diagnostic algorithms versus choosing alternative treatments
Decision point: how to frame treatment options to patients (framing effect in patient choice)
failures: Commission bias: tendency toward action rather than inaction, leading to unnecessary treatment
Satisfaction of search: stopping diagnostic search prematurely after finding something of interest
Availability error: applying common experiences to new cases while ignoring important differences
Anchoring error: allowing initial symptoms or findings to cloud clinical judgment
Attribution error: fitting patients into stereotyped roles based on past experiences or colleague reports
aha_moments: Finding something satisfactory in diagnosis is not equivalent to finding everything necessary
Clinically equivalent statements framed differently produce different patient responses
The ability to know when to deviate from algorithms improves with patient experience
Medical curricula inadequately prepare students for understanding cognitive biases in decision-making
metaphors: Cognitive traps as pitfalls physicians fall into during decision-making
temporal: Before reading the book: medical students learn little about cognitive errors and biases
After reading the book: understanding of how to recognize and correct cognitive biases improves
Temporal progression: ability to apply algorithms contextually improves the more patients one treats
quotes: Language is still the foundation of clinical medicine
Understanding why we sometimes get things wrong is important—if not essential—to understanding how to get things right
A 30% chance of improvement might be more positively received than a 70% chance of failure and death, even though both statements are clinically equivalent
